subject: RE: [junit] Message texts

messageBody:
-----Original Message-----
From: David Plass [mailto:dplass@...]
Sent: Wednesday, July 21, 2004 6:56 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Message texts


>So you'd write
assertTrue("someBoolean is not true!", someBoolean);

>Or as another example
assertEquals("The answer isn't the same!", expected, actual);



Probably best to replace 'someBoolean' or 'answer' with the idea of what you
are testing, as in 'The surname did not match the one I was looking for'.
Or, 'The ages of the clients are not equal'.

I am sure you probably have quite a few booleans in your code that you are
checking, but JB's suggestion was to put something meaningful that you can
come back and recognise when debugging later on. Having just 'someBoolean'
does not really tell you much does it...
Having an individual description will let you know exactly where the failure
occurred, but creates just that little bit of overhead when creating the
assertion itself.


Regards

CW
